turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Yoru no Odoriko.
turn.1: What did the critics say about Yoru no Odoriko?
turn.2: They further praised Yamaguchi's "human" vocals, feeling the techniques he used showed a J-Pop style to them, and the song's "catchy melody".
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Hiraga called the song a further re-imagination of the band's dance music sound, praising the song's "fresh lyrics and melody".
turn.5: Did anyone else have anything to say about it?
turn.6: Hanako Fujita of "Rockin' On Japan" felt similarly about the song's "literary" lyrics and sound, believing that the song's progression showed off Sakanaction's "musical charm".
turn.7: What did Fujita have to say?
turn.8: She thought of the song's lyrical message as being very effective, and believed that listeners could happily let the song take over themselves because of its "vivid and steady world of sound".
turn.9: Is there anything else of significance that the critics liked?
turn.10: In it first week, "Yoru no Odoriko" reached number five on Oricon's top 200 singles chart, selling 31,000 physical copies (approximately the same number that rival sales tracking agency "SoundScan Japan" noted).
turn.11: Did it stay on the charts long?
turn.12: The single quickly fell out of the top ten, falling to number 19 in its second week, and spent five further weeks in the top 100 singles.
